Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 11:10AM - edited Jan 2, 2009 11:11AM by angeljoy Suze, I'm so sorry you had to have your implants removed. Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2009 09:04PM angeljoy wrote: Hi, I had ILC in only one breast as well and opted for a bilateral. Not even when I was diagnosed could anyone feel this cancer in my breast. It didn't show up on mammography or ultrsound much, just as a "vague area". Not only is this a "sneaky" cancer, as mentioned above, but it is somewhat more likely than ductal cancer to recur in the other breast. So I just felt safer being rid of the breast tissue on both sides. I have never regreted that decison. Also, I had decided on reconstruction and being large breasted and saggy at 50, I felt I could achieve symmetry easier with a bilateral.  My surgeon didn't bring up the idea of the bilateral with me either, but when asked about it, felt that my reasons were good ones. It is however a very individual and personal decision.  There are many women who don't see the sense in removing a healthy breast.  I wish you the best, and peace in your decison.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 08:32PM angeljoy wrote: I had bilateral mastectomies in Nov. 07.  I was terrified of surgery and general anesthesia.  And I mean terrified!  One thing that helped me was to tell everyone how scared I was on the day of my surgery.  The surgeon, nurses, and especially the anesthesiologist were very comforting once I told them that.  I remember the anesthesiologist told me in the OR that he wanted me to have good dreams while I was asleep, so to think of myself on a beautiful beach somewhere.  That's what I did and it helped calm me.  I've had a few more surgeries since then and while I'm not quite as scared, I still don't like surgery, and I still tell them every time how frightened I am. ALL of this is very scary and overwhleming, especially at first. I remember thinking that I'd wake up and realize it was all just a bad dream. Sometime I still think that a year and a half later. It's had to believe now, but it WILL get better. You will learn how to cope.  Take everything one step at a time as much as you can. We are all here for you! Soon after my diagnosis someone gave me a little "courage angel" figurine.  She's got her arms raised up over her head like she just experienced some wonderful triumph.  Whenever I had something scary to face, I'd look at her or close my eyes and visualize her.  Somehow that helped. Keeping you in my prayers, Angela
